awd_titl_txt: CDS&E: Development and application of cluster-integral methods for dispersions and complex solutions
awd_abstract_narration:
With this award, the the Chemical Theory, Models and Computational Methods Program in the Chemistry Division is supporting David Kofke and Andrew Schultz of the University at Buffalo/SUNY to develop a hierarchal theoretical and computational approach to studying chemical solutions.  Chemical solutions are ubiquitous in natural and man-made systems, and their behavior is critical to many applications in technology, including healthcare, energy storage, environmental preservation, and food and consumer products. One approach to the description of chemical solutions is via a hierarchy of solute interactions, considering first the solute molecules individually, then taken in pairs, then groups of three, four, and so on. Each level in this hierarchy introduces new information about the mixture, such that one can infer the full behavior by proper analysis of these interactions. The quantities needed for this formulation can in principle be computed from detailed molecular considerations, which is desirable because it leads to greater predictive and descriptive capability. However, the means to perform these calculations for practical purposes have not been developed, so the full potential of the overall approach is relatively untested.  Developing and benchmarking this approach is the focus of this research projects.   The project integrates training of graduate students with outreach activities and development of learning materials and computer-based tools that permit others to benefit from the developments in this project.

The osmotic virial equation forms the theoretical framework the work. The research objectives of are: (1) to develop robust and accurate methods for calculating osmotic virial coefficients up to at least 5th order, from a molecular model, while formulating approximants that extend their reach; (2) to examine behavior of mixtures of hard convex particles, focusing in particular on entropy-driven aggregation and fluid-fluid phase instability. High-throughput screening using these cluster-integral methods is anticipated to yield data for at least 5000 species pairs; (3) to investigate association of proteins in solution, considering in particular the effect of crowder molecules on this behavior.

por.por_cntn:
A major obstacle to the further advancement of engineering and science stems from our limited ability to predict the properties of materials, considering their dependence on the temperature, density, and what they are composed of. Molecular-based thermodynamics and simulation is a major tool that is employed as a means to surmount this issue. The aim is to begin from a molecular model (ideally derived from fundamental physics, but usually that is too hard to do for practical problems, so semi-empirical forms are used), and to compute the properties that would emerge from molecules that interact according to this model. Molecular simulation is a reliable means to do this, but it is computationally expensive to get results with a useful level of precision. Molecular theories are sometimes employed, and these are fast to compute but not as reliable as simulation.

In this work we explored a framework based on osmotic virial coefficients as an approach that employs the best features of molecular simulation and molecular theory. The intellectual merit of the project is found in (1) the well-formed framework on which our developments were performed, (2) the creative means by which we developed and applied approaches within it to yield precise and accurate properties with a relatively low computational effort. More specifically, we examined several ways to compute osmotic virial coefficients for the description of solution phases. In the process of doing so, we identified a new, very general treatment (called mapped averaging) that guides the formulation of completely new equations that can be used to compute properties from molecular simulations with unprecedented efficiency (see figure for an example of its application). The approach uses approximate theories as a starting point, and produces equations that represent the correction to the theory in a form that is suitable for calculation by molecular simulation. Some well-established formulas, as well as others that have started to emerge independently, are shown to be special cases of the mapped averaging framework that we developed in this project. This means that mapped averaging can be applied systematically to go beyond these other formulas. We have shown, for example, that we can extend beyond a well-established formula for the pressure by including a term involving the virial coefficient that is second-order in density. We have also developed completely novel, and effective, formulas for calculation of dielectric properties of fluid phases. Many more avenues to properties have been opened for exploration by this development, extending now well beyond what is possible to examine in this project.

Additional activities involved computation of implicit-solvent osmotic virial coefficients for some hard-core models, which are models that treat a molecule as a rigid, elastic body with a well-defined shape. Such models are appropriate for colloidal systems formed from nanoparticles, as well as polymers in solution.  We calculated these coefficients for a large number of convex shapes (e.g., tetrahedron), and to very high (eighth) order in density, and find that the coefficients predict behavior well (in comparison to molecular simulation) when used in conjunction with a mathematical treatment that accelerates the convergence of the osmotic virial series. Further, as an example of broader impact, we developed software (with partial support from NIST) that allows anyone to compute these coefficients for particles that are modeled as assemblies of hard spheres. This code is being introduced in a well-used general-purpose computer program that is maintained by NIST for the calculation of a large range of particle properties. Our contribution is the first component of this code that computes multiparticle properties (existing capabilities are focused on single-particle properties, such as the volume, the electrical capacity, etc.).  Finally, the project spanned several years and contributed in part to the PhD education of three students and to the MS education of one student.  The training that these students received in molecular thermodynamics and simulation, as well as good software-engineering practices, represents additional broader impact.
